Parents:

It appears one of our security vendors has had a major issue that has caused the reset of 250+ student and staff Google passwords.

What does this mean?

Those affected will be unable to login to their Google/Zoom/Schoology/Seesaw/Clever accounts until the issue is resolved.

Can it get fixed?

Yes. We anticipate elementary passwords will be reset before secondary. This means that the passwords will be reset to what was used successfully earlier today. Secondary (Grades 6-12) is a little more problematic; a reset may involve a manual reset with HSD support or a mass reset using a new assigned password.

What is the HSD doing?

Our tech department is currently reaching out to affected teachers to help them get their passwords reset so they can resume instruction. Please understand that instruction may not happen today. If they can, teachers will reach out to families with an update.

We are also working with the vendor to figure out what happened, create a solution, and ensure that this does not happen again.

Thank you for your patience.

post_text: Preserving the Hockinson War Memorial, like most any undertaking, was a team effort. HSD employee Chris Chapman pressure washed the structure. HSD Superintendent Steve Marshall and two of his children stained it and neighbor Jim Misner provided the Marshalls with the painting supplies. Misner also helped lead the charge in 2009 to replace the former structure, which had fallen into disrepair. This project was timely - it was 75 years ago today that Japan surrendered to the United States, ending WW2.

post_text: TBT: Did you ever wonder who was the "Morgan" in Morgan Creek? One of Hockinson's first homes belonged to Lewis and Adalaide Morgan and their eight children. The home was located near the intersection of 182nd Ave and 164th St. Incidentally, Morgan Creek runs under 174th St, which was originally named John Nelson Road. John and his wife Johanna were married in 1880 and raised seven children in Hockinson. The Nelson family donated the property for Finn Hill Cemetery.

This week's TBT comes from nearly 50 years ago and provides the backstory for one of our local landmarks: The Hockinson War Memorial.

In the Spring of 1973, Jack Weber - the father of HHS teacher Beth Tugaw - led an effort to honor those Hockinson students who gave their lives in World War II and the Vietnam War. The project was made possible by funds raised by the HSD's 9th Grade Class of '73 (before it moved on to attend Battle Ground HS) as well as donations by the junior high's PTA and individual benefactors. While the drinking fountain was removed years ago, the original bronze plaque remains:

By the early 2000s, the memorial had fallen into disrepair and in 2008 the structure was rebuilt on the original foundation.

Q: What is going on at the HSD's old middle school site?

A: A lot of work! Due to the closure this spring, our custodial and maintenance staff are ahead of schedule. So they have stepped up to a number of special projects! One of these projects is the renovation of the building that formerly housed the district's middle school. The building is getting a fresh coat of paint inside and out. Roof repairs and new carpet are next.

What is in store for this building? Be on the lookout for an exciting update later this month. We hope that this old building will fulfill a new educational purpose that, like its refreshed appearance, will enhance the Hockinson community.

Hockinson Main Street Team
June 10 at 11:08 AM ·

Say hello to the Hockinson Main Street Team! We believe that we live and work in a pretty special place. Our purpose is to help build community, believing that everyone benefits from a more connected community.
Each month we will share opportunities to connect from our schools, businesses, faith community, and more. Over time we will even work to add some events of our own (The Tree Lighting was our first).
The team is made up of a group of volunteers who believe Hockinson is the best "census-designated place" in America.

Late-Breaking item: This Friday there will be a Celebration Cruise to celebrate our Hockinson High School Seniors. We will share a link to the event later on. Let's cheer on our Hawks!

On this #throwbackthursday, we’re talking about sisu! “What the heck is that?” you may be asking... As explained in this archived Columbian article about life in Hockinson, “sisu” is a Finnish word for courage and a sort of never-give-up-despite-the-odds determination. The woman explaining that meaning is none other than Gerda Mattson, whose family ties to the HSD run deep. In the article, Gerda talks about using "sisu" to raise three children on a 40-acre Hockinson farm by herself. 😮

In honor of the sisu tradition in Hockinson, HSD Superintendent Steve Marshall presented staff members with a "Sisu Award" last week for their ongoing determination and can-do spirit! Yes, they earned it without the 40-acre farm factor 😉

Let’s go “By the Numbers” and look at how district staff and teachers are learning too!

Since March 16, HSD classified staff have completed more than 2,300 hours of online professional development! Here’s why:

Since our students are not on campus, many of our classified staff have been unable to complete their normal job responsibilities. We appreciate that nearly all of our employees have taken advantage of the opportunity to learn more about topics that increase awareness, improve skills, and make us more aligned as a school district. These professional learning opportunities include courses on Adverse Childhood Experiences, student bullying, school security, family and student privacy laws, and diversity in schools. HSD staff have also taken trainings on Google-based apps which will enable them to work more efficiently and support our students with their projects.

The bottom line is our students aren’t the only ones learning online 😊

Let’s go “By the Numbers” and look at district’s food service program!

Did you know? The HSD has provided 24,600 meals at no cost to HSD students during the school closure! These meals are funded by a federal USDA program and available through the end of the school year to ALL students – not just to those who qualify for the Free and Reduced Lunch Program.

If you are interested, but have not yet signed up, please fill out the short registration & order form in the “Nutrition Services” section at www.hocksd.org/Content2/closureresources.

HSD families have the option of ordering meals on a daily or weekly basis. Meals may be ordered for any day (M-F) as long as the order is submitted by 4 p.m. the day prior (Example: To receive meal service on Tuesday, your order must be turned in by 4 p.m. Monday). Meals may also be ordered on a weekly basis as long as that option is specified on the form.

To cancel your order, or if you have any questions, please call HSD Nutrition Services as (360) 448-6481.

WE LOVE PETS TOO BUT....
Although the HHES play structure remains closed to prevent COVID transmission, the HSD has opened to the HMS and HHS campuses to outdoor activities during this school closure. The favorable spring weather has encouraged a large number of community members and families to flock to these schools. We are happy to see our outdoor facilities in use! We are unhappy, though, that some people are ignoring signs and bringing dogs and bikes on campus. Dogs and dog waste present health and liability concerns and bike use damages the surfacing on our tracks, which is very expensive to repair.
Thank you for your cooperation.

Heroes among us! Two weeks ago, Hockinson High School juniors Eva Sarkinen and Emilee Tikka were driving down the street when a group of kids ran outside and flagged them down. The students were ushered into a home and quickly discovered local resident Ashley Eggleston laying on the floor unresponsive. The quick-thinking students were scared, but didn’t panic. They dialed 9-1-1 and performed CPR on Ashley until emergency responders arrived.

Days later, following recovery, Ashley was able to meet Eva and Emilee. On that day, Ashley wrote, “When these girls stopped by today, I felt like I was literally holding onto angels sent straight from God. I know without a doubt that He sent them right when my babies and I needed them there.”

Way to go Eva and Emilee! Your community is so proud! 💙

Due to repeated acts of vandalism during the evening hours at Hockinson High School, the school's front parking lot gate will be locked at 9 PM. This will take effect on Friday, July 12.

We want our schools to be accessible for community use. So this decision will not impact the current level of access during daylight hours at HHS or any other HSD campus.

This change in hours is temporary. This gate will be open during normal hours when school activities resume in August.

Thank you for your understanding.

HHES's recent Multicultural STEAM Night was a success! Families shared their cultural heritages with the community while enjoying performances, snacks, art and STEAM -- science, technology, engineering, arts and math -- activities from around the world!

Multiple generations worked together to launch air rockets, build gliders and towers, show off their coding skills, and engineer creative designs at STEM stations. Students also showcased their art pieces and performed music inspired by cultures from six continents. (Antarctica was featured as a water station, surrounded by research articles and science paraphernalia.)

Members of the Hockinson community joined together to perform folk songs from around the world as students sang, played instruments and moved to the music!

The Illumi Rainbow Dance Company put on two beautiful shows, and the community cheered as the performers fused science, technology, engineering, and math into a performing arts masterpiece.

Thank you to Hockinson School District, WEA-Riverside and Hockinson PWT for sponsoring this amazing experience!

Deputized as citizen scientists with the Clark County Student Watershed Monitoring Network, they ran tests and collected data on water quality and habitat, and uploaded it to a database shared with other area schools.

As part of their ecosystems unit, our scientists will head back to the wetlands a couple more times this school year to gather more data.

The SWMN is a partnership of Vancouver’s Water Resources Education Center and Clark County’s Clean Water Division.

post_text: Our Hornets are learning ways to conserve resources, share with friends and help the planet. Congratulations to HHES and its Green Team!
shared_text:
Clark County Green Schools
November 6, 2018 at 3:13 PM ·

Congratulations to Hockinson Heights Elementary for their FIRST Washington Green Schools certification in Waste and Recycling! Their passionate Green Team tackled their cafeteria waste last year and implemented two Sort Tables so students could easily sort their recyclables, food waste and garbage. They also now have a Share Table where students pass on their unopened milk or packaged food for someone else to eat, rather than throwing it in the garbage. That's amazing!
A 5th grader last year said, “We started the composting and recycling project to help save the earth and throw away less trash. We were filling up four garbage bags a day and now we are only filling up one."
Thanks for your great support Hockinson School District!
